title: algorithms - Testing Randomness of Permutation Sequences
body: Maybe this question is too simple, but I couldn't find anything that is concerned with measuring how random a sequence of permutations of $n$ elements( w.l.o.g. of the numbers $\lbrace 1,\ \dots,\ n \rbrace\ $ ) is. For sequences of numbers or points there are quite a few tests available, that have to be passed to qualify as sufficiently random, i.e. lacking discernible patterns. Questions: is there something like the Diehard Tests for sequences of permutations of a fixed set of elements? which random permutation generators are considered "safe"? algorithms random-permutations Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jun 15, 2020 at 7:27 Community Bot 1 2 2 silver badges 3 3 bronze badges asked May 20, 2017 at 13:21 Manfred Weis 14k 4 4 gold badges 40 40 silver badges 82 82 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 3 $\begingroup$ I think you need to provide more details. For instance, what is your sampling space? If you are just selecting a member of a set with n! elements with uniform probability, is this problem not trivial? What do you mean by generators? $\endgroup$ thedude –  thedude 2017-05-20 14:46:54 +00:00 Commented May 20, 2017 at 14:46 $\begingroup$ @thedude I don't want to select just one member, but a representative sample of manageable size, analogous to asking 1000 carefully selected people instead of several millions to get representative answers. In the same manner I want a set of representative permutations, of which I can test certain properties and be sure, that the results are not much different when performing the tests on all permutations. A generator is an algorithm or device, that produces sequences of permutations. $\endgroup$ Manfred Weis –  Manfred Weis 2017-05-20 15:16:34 +00:00 Commented May 20, 2017 at 15:16 $\begingroup$ @thedude, a lot of effort has gone into solving the "trivial" problem of selecting a member of a finite set with uniform probability.
